channel.title: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?
channel.description:
Hello. I have made a VB app and am having trouble making it so that it sends the form to my e-mail.
Picture:
[IMG]http://i50.tinypic.com/2h6cz05.png[/img]
All help is appreciated. Btw, Idk if this is allowed on Mopar forums. Please tell me if it is allowed in this topic.
-Thanks

item.title: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?
item.dc:creator: @VbCoder VbCoder
item.description:
@VbCoder wrote:

Oh… misunderstanding…
I didn’t try to say that I made it, I ment that I didn’t had time to explain it a little bit.
I quickly copied & pasted it from and old project + edited it a little bit.

I wanted to say that he could change mail.Subject = ("SUBJECT...") to mail.Subject = textbox1.text if his textbox1.text was the textbox he wanted to send.

But nvm, just a misunderstanding i guess…

Read full topic

Lol, really pathetic that you rep-- me because I tried to help someone (;[/quote]I didn’t rep-- you because you tried to help, I rep-- you because of what you said:

I hope you understand most of it, [b]just did it quickly because I got to go now, goodluck[/b]...

People that have known me a while know that the one thing I hate most of all is people leeching.

item.source: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?

item.title: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“VbCoder, post:7, topic:342760”]Put this in the button that should send something:

    Dim smtpserver As New SmtpClient()
    Dim mail As New MailMessage()
    smtpserver.Credentials = New Net.NetworkCredential("YOURGMAILACCHERE@gmail.com", "YOURGMAILACCPASSHERE")
    smtpserver.Port = 587
    smtpserver.Host = "smtp.gmail.com"
    smtpserver.EnableSsl = True
    mail = New MailMessage()
    mail.From = New MailAddress("YOURGMAILACCHERE@gmail.com")
    mail.To.Add("SENDTOME@hotmail.com")
    mail.Subject = ("SUBJECT...")
    mail.Body = ("What is in the mail...")
    smtpserver.Send(mail)

I hope you understand most of it, just did it quickly because I got to go now, goodluck…[/quote]http://www.codeproject.com/KB/IP/Sending_Emails_From_GMAIL.aspx?display=Print

Way to not give credit to the actual tutorial maker.

Read full topic
item.source: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?

item.title: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?
item.dc:creator: @VbCoder VbCoder
item.description:
@VbCoder wrote:

Put this in the button that should send something:

Dim smtpserver As New SmtpClient() Dim mail As New MailMessage() smtpserver.Credentials = New Net.NetworkCredential("YOURGMAILACCHERE@gmail.com", "YOURGMAILACCPASSHERE") smtpserver.Port = 587 smtpserver.Host = "smtp.gmail.com" smtpserver.EnableSsl = True mail = New MailMessage() mail.From = New MailAddress("YOURGMAILACCHERE@gmail.com") mail.To.Add("SENDTOME@hotmail.com") mail.Subject = ("SUBJECT...") mail.Body = ("What is in the mail...") smtpserver.Send(mail)
I hope you understand most of it, just did it quickly because I got to go now, goodluck...

Read full topic

You should probably use Lins example.

item.source: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?

item.title: Visual Basic - How to make it so that it send the form that you fill out to me?
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Just create a string that contains the contents of your form. For example (I haven’t used VB in a long time, so my syntax may not be perfect):

Public Function GetFormString() As String Dim s As String = ""; s += "Name: " + txtName.Text + VbNewLine 'Might wanna check that last one. I know there is a constant defined for it somewhere s += "Age: " + txtAge.Text + VbNewLine return s End FunctionEtc…

Then Google on sending e-mails in .NET. Most likely the first page you’ll find will contain the answer you’re looking for.

Read full topic
